Class TimeSeriesJsonUtil

public final class TimeSeriesJsonUtil extends Object
Utility methods for working with TimeSeries.JSON data.

Jacob Dreyer

  • Method Details

    • getLineLength

      public static int getLineLength(TimeSeriesJson timeSeries)
      Return the line length of the specified time series, being the number of bytes of the binary representation of a single line of data of the time series.
      Parameters:
      timeSeries - Time series to get line length from. Non-null.
      Returns:
      The requested line length. [0,>.
      Throws:
      IllegalArgumentException - If timeSeries is null.

    • toLoggingString

      public static String toLoggingString(TimeSeriesJson timeSeries)
      Return a logging friendly text string of the specified time series.

      We write 4 data lines of a time series at most: 

         [index0, ...]
   [index1, ...]
   :
   [indexn, ...]
      Parameters:
      timeSeries - Time series to create logging friendly string for. Non-null.
      Returns:
      The requested string. Never null.

    • addLatencySignal

      public static String addLatencySignal(TimeSeriesJson timeSeries, String signalName, String signalDescription, boolean isTotalLatency)
      A simple way to keep track of latency within a system or a pipeline is to add time stamp or latency signal to the time series. This method will add the specified latency signal to the given time series and compute latency from similar signals added earlier. The signal should have a numeric suffix, like TIME_T8 etc. or such a suffix will be added. The first signal of this pattern added will contain a timestamp (long values of milliseconds since Epoch) while later signals added will contain the latency (in milliseconds) since the previous signal was added. Signals may not be a consecutive sequence. TIME_T0 can be followed by TIME_T4 and so on.
      Parameters:
      timeSeries - The time series to add latency signal to. Non-null.
      signalName - Name of signal to add. A numeric suffix is added if the name doesn't contain one already.
      signalDescription - Signal description, typically describing the performed task responsible for the latency. May be null.
      isTotalLatency - True to make a grand total of latency signals added earlier, false to make it a regular latency signal.
      Returns:
      Actual name of the curve added. Never null.
      Throws:
      IllegalArgumentException - If timeSeries or curveName is null.
